page.title: 11LONGFORGAN - MARKET CROSS -
page.content: In 1672 Longforgan was erected to a free burgh of the barony in a charter granted by Charles II to Patrick, Earl of Strathmore and Kinghorn. Sometime later, the exact date is uncertain, the Earl presented a cross to the village similar to one in the grounds of Glamis Castle. It is described as a pillar of stone with a lion on top of several steps of masonry and is 21feet high. In approx. 1797 the cross was taken from its site outside the school gates to a site known as Cromwell's Knowe in the grounds of Castle Huntly where it is currently. It has been agreed by the Secretary of State that the cross should be re-sited in the village after requests by the Community Council. Final negotiations for the site of and for the re-siting of the Market Cross are currently taking place.
